clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluation of Block Duration in Type 2 Diabetes Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Comparison of Subgluteal Sciatic Nerve Block Duration in Type-2 Diabetic and Non Diabetic Patients

brief_summary.textblock: Diabete animal studies demonstrated a longer period recovery after local anesthetic injection (perineural administration). No clinical study demonstrated a prolonged nerve block duration in diabete type 2 patients after peripheral nerve block. The investigators hypothesized that block recovery is delayed in diabetic patients.

detailed_description.textblock: For diabetic patients, peripheral nerve block is an interesting alternative to general anesthesia because it provides effective analgesia and may decrease haemodynamic complication. The fear of nerve injury after regional anaesthesia in diabetic patients is a concern that has neither been confirmed nor refuted by current literature. As a matter of fact, diabetic patients with neuropathy may be considered at increased risk because of the possibility for double crush syndrome when a chronic axon lesion related to diabetes is associated with an unexpected distal nerve injury related to regional anaesthesia.

primary_outcome.measure: the duration of sensory block in hours
primary_outcome.description: The beginning of this term is defined by the end of the sciatic block injection, and the end of this period is defined by the reappearance of sensitivity to pin-prick test

secondary_outcome.measure: the duration of motor sciatic block
secondary_outcome.description: The beginning of this term is defined by the end of the sciatic block injection, and the end of this period is defined by the reappearance of motor function

other_outcome.measure: Time necessary for onset sensory and motor block time in minutes

arm_group.description: Patient with type 2 diabete received 20 mL ropivacaine

intervention.description: patients received 20 mL ropivacaine 5 mg/mL on subgluteal nerve

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- age (50 80 yrs) with monofilament test 10 g (> 4/8)
Exclusion Criteria:
- refusal of sciatic nerve block,
- age < 50 yr or > 80 yr,
- American Society of Anesthesiologists state > IV,
- presence of contraindications to local anaesthesia (known allergy to local anaesthetics, sepsis),
- emergency surgery,
- patients unlikely to be fully cooperative during the study,
- psychiatric disorders, or
- those abusing alcohol or drugs, and
- participation in another study within the previous 30 days. Moreover, patients with preoperative estimated values of creatinine clearance < 50 mL min-1 (Cockroft and Gault Formula) or with glycosylated hemoglobin (A1c) level > 8 % or with type 1 diabetes mellitus (insulin therapy)
